note.p: “It was a little peaceful bay” (MS VIII; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—The little bay, which is the point of embarkation for the familyʼs first excursion on the Italian lakes, apparently refers to Lago Mezzola rather than Lago di Como, the main subject of the poem. In her travel diary for 14 June 1833, Mary Richardson records that the family left Chiavenna at six oʼclock in the morning for nearby “Riva”—by which she must have meant what Murrayʼs guidebook identifies as “Lago Mezzola, called also Lago di Riva”, and what Starkeʼs guidebook refers to simply as “La Riva”. Describing the journey in Praeterita, Ruskin called the place “the little recessed lake of Chiavenna” (Ruskin, Works, 35:116).

These movements are in keeping with the recommendations of the guidebooks. Murray cautioned travelers against pausing on their journey through these lakes, particularly “the lower valley of the Meira” (or Mera River), which connects “Chiavenna to the Lago di Riva” (i.e., Lago di Mezzola) and then continues onward to connect the latter to Lago di Como. Travelers should push onward, Murray urged, until reaching either Bellagio on the promontory dividing the lower legs of Lago di Como, or Cadenabbia on the west shore, or Varenna on the east shore. Until travelers reached those points south, Murray sternly lectured, they risked contracting malaria: “the stranger who neglects this warning may pay for his temerity by a fever” since “stopping for the night [anywhere] near the embouchure of a river, where it empties itself into a lake”, exposes the traveler to “the morasses and flat land created by the deposits of the river”, which “are the hotbeds of malaria, and inevitably teem with disease” (Hand‐book for Travellers in Switzerland, 212, xxiii). Mariana Starke, in her guidebook, confirms a lesser detail in Maryʼs account—that a separate boat conveyed the familyʼs carriage from Lago di Riva to Como, while the family took a small passenger boat, until joining a steamer at Domaso. Starke mentions that the steamer concession at Domaso was “managed by Englishmen” (Starke, Travels in Europe, 568).

As additional evidence that the location of the “little peaceful bay / Beneath the precipices grey”, where Ruskin begins his poem, must have been on Lago di Riva, the narrator mentions further on that, having “launched from below / The shade of the tall cliffs”, the family arrives, at line 20, where “Como rolled his breast of flame”. Lago di Riva is indeed a place of cliffs coming down to the sea, and perhaps would have appeared even more dramatically so in 1833, before a road was built around the perimeter of the lake. Murray mentions such a road as having opened in 1835. Ruskinʼs “thousand mountain rills” among these cliffs are likewise remarked by Murray: “The naked and savage mountains around have a very peculiar outline. Their sides are furrowed with ravines, down which furious torrents precipitate themselves . . . , strewing the margin of the lake with wreck” (Hand‐book for Travellers in Switzerland, 212). The strategy of the poem is to contrast this severe scene with the blue Como and its richly vegetated banks, which forms the subject of the remainder of the poem. Note that Ruskin does not mention the steamer, describing only the splash of oars in the water. By confining his description to the gentle sounds of the excursion on the small passenger boat, he was erasing such signs of modernity as the noisy steam packet for the sake of maintaining the picturesque, just as in “Calais” he replaced the “french steamer” on the horizon with the picturesque, lugubrious movements nearby of French fishing boats.

As detailed in the textual notes to this poem, W. G. Collingwood omitted the first ten lines of the MS VIII draft from the version of the poem in Poems (1891), an omission that effectively erases the prelude describing Lago Mezzola and focuses the poem on Lago di Como.
